text: was an old province of Japan in the area of Toyama Prefecture on the island of Honshū.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Etchū" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 183. Along with Echizen and Echigo Provinces, it was sometimes called . The province had borders with Echigo, Shinano, Hida, Kaga, and Noto provinces. The capital city of the province was Takaoka. ==History== The Noto Peninsula and Noto Province was separated from Etchū during the reign of Empress Genshō.Meyners d'Estrey, Guillaume Henry Jean (1884). Annales de l'Extrême Orient et de l'Afrique, Vol. 6, p. 172; excerpt, Genshō crée sept provinces : Idzumi, Noto, Atoa, Iwaki, Iwase, Suwa et Sado en empiétant sur celles de Kawachi, Echizen, Etchū, Kazusa, Mutsu and Shinano In the Meiji period, the provinces of Japan were converted into prefectures. The maps of Japan and Etchū Province were reformed in the 1870s.Nussbaum, "Provinces and prefectures" at p. 780. ==Shrines and Temples== Takase jinja, Keta jinja and Oyama jinja were the chief Shinto shrines (ichinomiya) of Etchū."Nationwide List of Ichinomiya," p. 2 . title: Etchū Province
